It is indicated that Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°{F}(\mathbf{w}) cannot
be calculated directly by following Table II due to the lack of usersâ€™ data at the BS. Instead, we refer to (5) for computing Fâ€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°{F}(\mathbf{w}) after global aggregation.

A proportion of loss functions are shown in Table II satisfying 1)-3) in Assumption 1. These loss functions are often used in some classification models and regression models, such as support vector machine (SVM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and linear regression, which will be examined later in our simulations in Section V. Regarding 4) of Assumption 1, gradient divergence reflects the difference among data distributions of all the users. If the data distributions are similar to each other, the gradient divergence will be small, and vice versa. Furthermore, 5) of Assumption 1 reflects the difference between model trained by FL and that trained by centralized machine learning.

references: We see that in different cases with the i.i.d. dataset, as Ï„ğœ\tau increases, the loss value decreases and predict accuracy improves. In the CNN model, the optimal Ï„ğœ\tau is large and close to 100100100 while close to 202020 in the SVM model. However, we see the loss value of CNN is stable when Ï„ğœ\tau is more than 202020. Therefore, to avoid overfitting, we set Ï„mâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğœğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥\tau_{max} to be 202020. In the non-i.i.d. dataset, the curves for the loss value represent a â€œUâ€ shape. The optimal Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™s are close to 101010, which is consistent with the analysis in Theorem 222. It indicates that training model with the non-i.i.d. data need more aggregations (e.g. a lower Ï„ğœ\tau). With the parameters setup in our simulations, the theoretical optimal Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™s in different cases are shown in Table V, which almost coincide with the numerical results in Fig. 1.

In the third part of our simulations, we compare the proposed algorithm with the baseline from [32], where the optimal Ï„ğœ\tau is given in Table V. Specifically, the following three categories of comparisons are considered, and their corresponding results are presented in Figs. 3-5.
